msItem.author: Gregory the Great
msItem.title: Homiliae in Ezechielem
msItem.incipit: Dei omnipotentis asspiratione de Ezechiel propheta locuturus
msItem.explicit: perpetuam perducit. Sit itaque gloria per omnia secula seculorum
msItem.note: Book I ends on fol. fol. 66r (‘Explicit omelia XII Gregorii papae’); fol. 66v is blank; Book II begins on fol. 67r.

supportDesc.support: parchment, with some uneven edges but rarely holes in the text area
supportDesc.foliation: i, 1–127, in pencil, in the usual style for Laud MSS.
supportDesc.collation: Uncertain: too tightly bound. No catchwords or quire signatures survive.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for two columns of 40 lines (Muzerelle 2-2-22/ 0/ 2-2/ JJ). Ruled space c. 270 175 with 25 mm. between columns.

handDesc.handNote: Several pre-gothic book hands; rubrics in orange majuscules (sometimes oxidised to a silvery appearance); marginal diples shaped like ‘ss’ highlight quotations. Changes of script occur at, e.g., fol. 58r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Large decorative initials in the inks of the main text and rubrics, usually outlined with lines of dots in the Insular manner, sometimes with rudimentary foliate or geometric ornament, occasionally with a pale yellow background wash (e.g. fol. 77r). 'Good archaizing initials' (Pächt and Alexander i. 46, pl. IV).

binding.p: Laudian binding. Sewn on five bands laced into pasteboards covered with polished brown leather, each cover stamped in gilt with the arms of Archbishop Laud, with vestiges of two ties; rebacked. Several medieval fore-edge tabs made of parchment knots using MS. waste (see e.g. fol. 14r–v).

origin.origPlace: German, Lotharingia (according to Pächt and Alexander)

history.provenance: 15th-cent ‘Nota’ marks, manicula, and other marginalia (e.g. fols. 51v, 101r).
William Laud, 1573–1645, with the usual inscription, here dated 1638 (fol. 1r, lower margin).
history.acquisition: Donated to the Bodleian Library in 1641 or later (Quarto Catalogue, p. xxxix). Former Bodleian shelfmarks: ‘A. 175’ (crossed through), ‘Laud 155’ (cancelled by encircling) (inside front cover), ‘A. 175.’ (fol. 1r).

recordHist.source: Description (May 2021) by Peter Kidd, edited by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885). Quarto Catalogue, col. 146 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 24

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, I (1966), no. 46

revisionDesc.change: Description revised for Polonsky German digitization project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
